stem: A 3-year-old child living in a home built in 1940 is admitted for sudden seizures and vomiting. Based on the documentation in the Pediatric Toxicology & Environmental Exposure Log tab, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Acute encephalopathy and seizures in a toddler.
Background: Parents report the child has been 'irritable' and was found chewing on windowsill paint.
Assessment: Child is currently obtunded (GCS 10) with projectile vomiting.
Recommendation: Blood lead level and ICP stabilization.

tabs.title: Toxicology & Environmental Log
tabs.content:

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: BP 118/74 (High for age), HR 68 (Slowing), RR 12, T 98.6Â°F.

actionOptions.text: Prepare for Chelation Therapy (e.g., Succimer or Edetate Calcium Disodium)
Initiate seizure precautions and maintain 30-degree HOB elevation
Administer an extra glass of milk to bind the lead in the stomach
Place the child in a bright room to stimulate neurological recovery

parameterOptions.text: Neurological status and presence of seizure activity
Urine output and renal function (Chelation toxicity risk)
Presence of a positive Babinski sign

rationale.correct: This is Lead-Induced Encephalopathy (c2) with acute Increased ICP. A lead level of 72 mcg/dL is critically high and can cause brain swelling, seizures, and permanent damage. Management requires Chelation Therapy (a1) to remove the lead from the body. Because the brain is swelling (ICP), seizure precautions and HOB elevation (a2) are mandatory. Monitoring focuses on the brain (p1) and the kidneys (p2), as chelation drugs are nephrotoxic.
clinicalPearls: Blood lead levels > 45 mcg/dL require medical treatment; levels > 70 are medical emergencies.
Lead competes with calcium in the brain, disrupting neurotransmitters and causing cerebral edema.
Always check the kidneys (BUN/Cr) before and during chelation therapy.

questionTrap.trap: Thinking 'distracting the child' is the priority during toxic encephalopathy.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: When the lead level is this high, it is a physiologic crisis, not a behavior issue. Treat the ICP and start chelation.
